benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails/{email} - Delete email from account

covered: DELETE Method - Valid Deletion: Multiple scenarios validate successful deletion returning 204 and confirm the email is removed from the account (TC01, TC02, TC12, TC13, TC14).
DELETE Method - Non-Existent Resource: Proper 404 handling when account or email does not exist, including the case where the account has no emails (TC03, TC04, TC09).
DELETE Method - Concurrency: Race condition covered with concurrent deletes; only one succeeds and the rest return 404 (TC15).
Header Validation: Required X-Killbill-CreatedBy enforced (TC07); optional X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment accepted (TC02).
Input Validation: Invalid UUID format and invalid email (including XSS) return 400 (TC05, TC06, TC16).
Authorization: Unauthorized access with invalid/expired token returns 401 (TC10).
Server Error Handling: Dependency/service failure returns 503 with appropriate error (TC11).
Resilience/Recovery: Transient network failure with retry succeeds (TC19).
Regression/Compatibility: Uppercase email handling and legacy client behavior validated (TC17, TC18).
gaps: DELETE Method - Soft Deletes: No explicit verification of soft vs hard delete semantics (e.g., confirm resource is permanently removed and not just flagged; attempt recovery or verify with a follow-up GET/list).
Response Headers and Media Type: No assertions that error responses use Content-Type: application/json per spec, nor that 204 responses have no body; no validation of standardized error schema.
URL Encoding of Path Parameter: No tests for URL-encoded email values or special characters (e.g., user+tag@example.com, percent-encoded @ as %40, spaces, unicode/punycode).
Idempotency (sequential): No scenario for repeating the same DELETE sequentially (first 204 then 404 or consistent idempotent behavior as defined).
Authorization - Forbidden: No test for 403 when token is valid but lacks required scope/permissions (if applicable).
Audit/Header Edge Cases: No boundary tests for header lengths, empty optional headers, or header injection (e.g., newline characters) on X-Killbill-* headers.
Rate Limiting/Throttling: No stress tests to observe behavior under high-frequency DELETE calls (if enforced by the platform).
recommendations: Add a soft-delete verification scenario: after DELETE, perform a GET of account emails to ensure the email is truly removed and not retrievable; if soft-delete is intended, verify the deleted flag and behavior explicitly.

Assert response headers and payload shape: verify Content-Type: application/json for error responses; ensure 204 responses have no body; validate error schema (code/message) across 400/401/403/404/503.
Add URL-encoding scenarios: DELETE using URL-encoded emails (e.g., user%2Btag%40example.com) and other special/unicode characters to confirm correct path parsing.
Add idempotency scenario: perform two sequential DELETEs for the same email and document/validate expected statuses (e.g., 204 then 404).
Extend authorization coverage with a 403 Forbidden test using a valid token lacking delete permissions (if RBAC applies).
Include header boundary tests: very long X-Killbill-CreatedBy/Reason/Comment, empty optional headers, and header injection attempts should be handled safely.
If applicable to your platform, add rate limiting tests to ensure proper responses and headers (e.g., 429, Retry-After) under burst DELETE requests.
